block.p: I.M.F. to Consider Changes In Conditions Put on Loans The International Monetary Fund, which has ordered developing nations to enact wrenching reforms as the price for emergency aid in recent years, is likely to curtail the demands it makes of clients who borrow money in the future, a senior fund official said.

Streamlining the conditions the I.M.F. imposes on borrowers is one of the changes Horst Kohler, the new managing director, is weighing as a panel he set up to study the agency's role finishes a draft report. [Page C2.]

Sepsis Drug Lifts Eli Lilly Shares Eli Lilly said that advanced trials of a drug it is developing to treat the bacterial infection sepsis had met its goals for lowering death rates. Zovant, if eventually approved, would be the first drug to treat complications of the disease, which kills 1,400 people a day worldwide. Lilly said it expected to submit an application to the Food and Drug Administration for approval by the first quarter of 2001. Shares of Lilly soared $15.125, to $102.25. [A18.]

Profit Warnings Pull Down Stocks Stock prices fell broadly as several prominent companies, including Ericsson, Unisys and Goodyear Tire, warned of lower-than-expected profits. The Nasdaq composite index slid 63.11 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,877.23. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 129.75 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,398.04. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 12.43 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,442.39. [C5.]
Bond yields fell sharply amid weakness in stocks and investor relief that the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. [C5.]

Airlines' Plans Hurt Priceline Stock Shares in Priceline.com dropped 8.4 percent after a report that six major airlines -- America West Airlines, American Airlines, Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines, United Airlines and US Airways -- plan to invest in a competing Web site for customers looking for discounts on plane tickets online. [C2.]

First-Quarter G.D.P. Revised Up Gross domestic product, the broadest measure of economic activity, grew at an annual rate of 5.5 percent in the first quarter instead of the 5.4 percent estimated a month ago, the Commerce Department said, raising the prospect of more interest-rate increases this year. [C2.]

Druckenmiller to Rejoin Duquesne Stanley Druckenmiller, who quit Soros Fund Management in April and also told investors in his Duquesne Capital Management fund group that he was taking a break, is now telling Duquesne investors that he will return in September, according to investors in the firm. Duquesne, based in Pittsburgh, has about $2 billion in assets from clients that include Bowdoin College, Mr. Druckenmiller's alma mater in Maine; Berea College in Kentucky; and Denison University in Ohio. [C2.]

Nominee for Commerce Secretary President Clinton nominated a former congressman, Norman Y. Mineta, as secretary of commerce for the rest of his presidency. Mr. Mineta would become the first Asian-American to hold a Cabinet post. [A15.]

Ford in Exclusive Talks for Daewoo Ford won exclusive rights to negotiate the purchase of Daewoo Motor of South Korea with a $6.9 billion offer that would be Ford's largest foreign acquisition and could significantly strengthen its operations in Asia. [C3.]

U.S. Proposes Changes in Subsidies The Clinton administration introduced a sweeping proposal at the World Trade Organization to change the way governments subsidize farmers, challenging the European Union's extensive agricultural subsidies. [C4.]
